sub_topic: Calculation of the electrical conductivity of a metal
message_1: Calculate the electrical conductivity of copper (Cu) at 298 K, given that its resistivity is 1.68 ×10^-8 Ωm. Assume that all electrons contribute to conduction and that the density of copper is 8.96 g/cm^3.
message_2:
To calculate the electrical conductivity of copper (Cu) at 298 K, we can use the formula:

Electrical conductivity (σ) = 1 / Resistivity (ρ)

Given that the resistivity of copper (ρ) is 1.68 × 10^-8 Ωm, we can calculate the electrical conductivity as follows:

σ = 1 / (1.68 × 10^-8 Ωm)

σ ≈ 5.95 × 10^7 S/m

So, the electrical conductivity of copper at 298 K is approximately 5.95 × 10^7 S/m.
